questions.title: Design Hit Counter (Bloomberg Variant)
questions.prompt: Design a HitCounter class that counts the number of hits received in the past 5 minutes. Implement `void hit(int timestamp)` and `int getHits(int timestamp)`. Optimize for O(1) time and space complexity.
followups: How do you handle out-of-order timestamps?
How would you make this thread-safe for concurrent requests?
What is the memory trade-off between using a queue vs a circular array?

questions.title: Lottery System (O(1) Storage)
questions.prompt: Design a lottery storage system that supports `addParticipant(id)`, `removeParticipant(id)`, and `pickWinner()` (random selection). All operations must run in O(1) time. Participants are identified by unique integer IDs.
followups: How do you ensure uniform random probability?
How do you handle removing a participant that is already removed?
Can you implement this in C++ without using the standard library's random shuffle?

questions.title: Combination Sum
questions.prompt: Given an array of distinct integers `candidates` and a target integer `target`, return a list of all unique combinations of `candidates` where the chosen numbers sum to `target`. You may use the same number an unlimited number of times.
followups: What is the time complexity of your solution?
How do you avoid duplicate combinations?
What if the array contains duplicates (Combination Sum II)?

questions.title: Number of Islands
questions.prompt: Given an `m x n` 2D binary grid `grid` which represents '1's (land) and '0's (water), return the number of islands. An island is surrounded by water and is formed by connecting adjacent lands horizontally or vertically.
followups: What is the space complexity if you use BFS vs DFS?
How would you solve this if the grid is too large to fit in memory (streaming)?
Can you solve it without modifying the input grid?

questions.title: Wordle Checker
questions.prompt: Implement a Wordle checker function. Given a `guess` word and a `target` word (both 5-letter strings), output a string that indicates: 'G' for correct letter in correct position, 'Y' for correct letter in wrong position, and 'B' for letter not in target. Handle duplicate letters correctly.
followups: How do you handle cases where a letter appears more times in the guess than in the target?
What if the words are not fixed length?
How would you optimize this for millions of guesses per second?

questions.title: Min Stack
questions.prompt: Design a stack that supports `push()`, `pop()`, `top()`, and retrieving the minimum element in constant time (`getMin()`).
followups: How do you handle duplicate minimum values?
What is the space complexity of your approach?
Can you implement it with O(1) extra space (store the difference)?

questions.title: Valid Triangle Number
questions.prompt: Given an integer array `nums`, return the number of triplets chosen from the array that can make triangles if we take them as side lengths.
followups: What is the time complexity of the two-pointer vs binary search approach?
How does sorting the array help?
What edge cases cause overflow in C++?

questions.title: LRU Cache (Variable Size)
questions.prompt: Design a Least Recently Used (LRU) cache with variable entry sizes. Implement `get(key)` and `put(key, value, size)`. The cache has a total capacity in bytes. Evict the least recently used items until there is enough space for the new entry.
followups: What data structure do you use to track the total size efficiently?
What happens if a single entry is larger than the total capacity?
How do you prevent cache pollution from large, infrequent entries?

questions.title: Find Peak Element
questions.prompt: A peak element is an element that is strictly greater than its neighbors. Given a 0-indexed integer array `nums`, find a peak element and return its index. The array may contain multiple peaks. Your solution must run in O(log n) time.
followups: Why does binary search work on an unsorted array?
What invariant do you maintain?
How do you handle plateaus (equal neighbors)?

questions.title: Box Nesting Problem (Containment Chains)
questions.prompt: You are given N six-sided boxes with dimensions (length, width, height). One side is open. Box A can fit inside Box B if: (1) min(A.l, A.w) < min(B.l, B.w), (2) max(A.l, A.w) < max(B.l, B.w), and (3) A.h <= B.h. Find the maximum nesting chain (i.e., box A -> box B -> box C).
followups: How do you sort the boxes to make this a LIS problem?
What if rotation is allowed on all axes?
How do you output the actual chain, not just the length?

questions.title: Flatten a Multilevel Doubly Linked List
questions.prompt: You are given a doubly linked list which in addition to the next and previous pointers, it has a `child` pointer, which may or may not point to a separate doubly linked list. Flatten the list so that all the nodes appear in a single-level, doubly linked list.
followups: Can you do it iteratively without using a stack?
How do you handle cycles in the child pointers?
What is the time and space complexity?

questions.title: Design Tic-Tac-Toe
questions.prompt: Design a Tic-Tac-Toe game that supports two players on an n x n board. Implement `move(row, col, player)` which returns whether the current player has won the game. Optimize for O(1) time per move.
followups: How do you track row, column, and diagonal sums without iterating?
How would you extend this to 3D Tic-Tac-Toe?
How do you detect a draw/tie condition?

questions.title: Rotate Matrix/Image
questions.prompt: You are given an n x n 2D matrix representing an image. Rotate the image by 90 degrees (clockwise) in-place.
followups: How do you rotate it counter-clockwise?
What is the space complexity of the transpose + reverse method?
How would you rotate a non-square matrix (m x n)?

questions.title: Count and Say
questions.prompt: The count-and-say sequence is a sequence of digit strings defined by a recursive formula. Given a positive integer `n`, return the `nth` term of the count-and-say sequence.
followups: What is the time complexity? (The length grows exponentially)
How would you optimize this for very large n?
Can you implement it iteratively?

questions.title: Group Anagrams
questions.prompt: Given an array of strings `strs`, group the anagrams together. You can return the answer in any order.
followups: What is the time complexity of sorting vs counting sort for the key?
What is the space complexity?
How would you handle very large inputs (streaming)?

questions.title: Expand Wildcard String
questions.prompt: Given a string `s` consisting of characters '0', '1', and '*' (wildcard), replace every '*' with either '0' or '1' and return all possible binary strings.
followups: What is the time complexity (2^k where k is number of wildcards)?
How would you do this iteratively using a queue?
What if the string is very long (1 million characters)?

questions.title: Find the Two Innermost Characters
questions.prompt: Given a string containing nested parentheses, find the two innermost characters within the deepest nesting level.
followups: How do you track the current depth?
What if there are multiple pairs at the same depth?
What characters are allowed besides parentheses?

questions.title: Path in Grid with Obstacles
questions.prompt: Given a 2D grid with obstacles (0 = free, 1 = obstacle), find if there is a path from the top-left corner to the bottom-right corner. You can only move down or right.
followups: How would you find the shortest path (BFS)?
How would you find all possible paths?
What if you can move in all 4 directions?

questions.title: Design Fair Event Registration Queue
questions.prompt: Design an in-memory service for an event registration system. Fairness means users are served strictly in the order they registered (FIFO). Implement `register(userId)`, `cancel(userId)`, and `next()`.
followups: How do you handle cancellations from the middle of the queue?
How do you achieve O(1) for all operations?
What if you need to prioritize VIP users?

questions.title: Top K Frequent Elements
questions.prompt: Given an integer array `nums` and an integer `k`, return the `k` most frequent elements. You may return the answer in any order.
followups: Can you do better than O(n log n)?
What is the worst-case time complexity of quickselect?
How would you handle a stream of data?

questions.title: Binary Tree Level Order Traversal
questions.prompt: Given the root of a binary tree, return the level order traversal of its nodes' values (i.e., from left to right, level by level).
followups: What is the space complexity in the worst case?
How would you do it using DFS?
How would you return a zigzag/spiral order?

questions.title: String Compression (with counts)
questions.prompt: Implement a method to perform basic string compression using the counts of repeated characters. For example, the string `aabcccccaaa` would become `a2b1c5a3`. If the compressed string is not shorter than the original, return the original.
followups: What is the time and space complexity?
How do you handle single characters?
How would you handle digits in the original string?

questions.title: Find Duplicate Subtrees
questions.prompt: Given the root of a binary tree, return all duplicate subtrees. For each kind of duplicate subtree, you only need to return the root node of any one of them. Two trees are duplicate if they have the same structure and same node values.
followups: How do you serialize a subtree efficiently?
What is the risk of using string concatenation?
How would you optimize memory usage?

questions.title: Implement Magic Dictionary
questions.prompt: Design a data structure that supports `buildDict(words)` and `search(word)` which returns true if there is a word in the dictionary that can be transformed into the search word by changing exactly one character.
followups: What are the trade-offs between generating neighbors vs using a trie?
How do you handle the 'exactly one' constraint?
What if the dictionary is very large (millions of words)?

questions.title: Simplify Path (Unix Style)
questions.prompt: Given a string `path`, which is an absolute path (starting with a slash '/') to a file or directory in a Unix-style file system, convert it to the simplified canonical path.
followups: How do you handle '..' and '.'?
What is the time complexity?
How would you handle a network/URL path instead of a file path?
